source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: The as-polished structure of the interface (Fig. 5a) clearly shows the "multiple cusped" irregular nature of the metal-oxide interface.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: Such irregularly shaped metal-oxide interfaces are observed by other investigators when corrosion occurred under either water or oxygen environment.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: The common feature is the breakdown of the coherency at the interface due to the presence of some precipitate (hydride in the case of water environment and other intermetallics in the oxygen environment).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: The common feature is the breakdown of the coherency at the interface due to the presence of some precipitate (hydride in the case of water environment and other intermetallics in the oxygen environment).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: it is reasonable to conclude that the dark features at the interface in Fig. $5 c$ are either hydrides or regions of the interface where coherency has been lost due to the fracture of the hydride precipitates.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: The metaloxide interface geometry shown in Fig. $5 c$ implies that the fracture of the substrate hydrides at the interface facilitates the advance of the oxidation front into the metal.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: Although the extent of hydride precipitates at the reactor operating temperature would be less than that shown by the micrograph obtained at the room temperature, the hydrogen level in the specimen (a) [12] is estimated to be higher than the high temperature solubility. Therefore hydrides would be present at the PWR operating temperature.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: In front of the metal-oxide interface on the metal side (Fig. 6a), some plate type precipitates are seen.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: energy dispersive X-ray measurements confirmed that these features, although rich in Zr content, were not associated with Fe and Cr enrichment corresponding to the normal second-phase particles in Zircaloy-4.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: It may be speculated that these features are fine zirconium hydrides precipitates near the interface.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: Figure $6 b$ shows a metaloxide interface for Specimen 7 that had a hydride orientation factor with a significant radial component.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: Specimens 7 has a recrystallized microstructure.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: Specimen 7 has a higher $f _ { N }$ factor associated with it.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: It appears that the oxide interface has advanced into the metal along a hydride precipitate.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: The SEM results shown in Fig. 6 provide additional support for the hypothesis that the fracture of hydride precipitates facilitates advancement of the oxidation front.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: the breakaway is associated with other precipitates (iron, chromium, and nickel-rich second-phase particles).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: For Specimen 2 (Fig. 7a). the hydrides were circumferential (i.e., a low value of hydride orientation factor $f _ { N }$ ), the hydrides were thick, and there was some tendency for banding (i.e., there were regions with hydride agglomeration as well as regions free of hydrides).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk4
evidence_span: For Specimen 2 (Fig. 7a). the hydrides were circumferential (i.e., a low value of hydride orientation factor $f _ { N }$ ), the hydrides were thick, and there was some tendency for banding (i.e., there were regions with hydride agglomeration as well as regions free of hydrides).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk6
evidence_span: The Zircaloy-4 corrosion test results at $6 3 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ and metallographic evidence obtained in the current investigation are consistent with a corrosion rate enhancement due to loss of coherency at the protective oxide sublayer-metal interface as a result of fracture of the hydride precipitates.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: Mechanical property data on zirconium hydride [32] show that below $7 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { K } }$ EPY $( 4 2 7 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ zirconium hydride is a brittle material and above this temperature it exhibits increasing ductility with increasing temperature.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: These high temperature tensile tests on hydrided zirconium containing 40 to 50.6 atomic percent hydrogen are judged to be a better representation of the mechanical properties of zirconium hydride than the rest of the more abundant data available for zirconium with lower levels of hydrogen (i.e., zirconium-hydride composites).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: At $7 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$ $( 4 2 7 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ with $5 0 . 6 \%$ hydrogen atomic $\%$ [32] both the reductions in area and elongations were in the range of 0 to $2 \%$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: At $7 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$ $( 4 2 7 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ with $5 0 . 6 \%$ hydrogen atomic $\%$ [32] both the reductions in area and elongations were in the range of 0 to $2 \%$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: For the normal in-reactor exposures. the interface temperatures are generally less than 623 K $( 3 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ ; therefore hydrides are brittle and are able to fracture in a brittle mode.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: In a 633 K water autoclave test, the hydrides are also brittle.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: For a $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ steam test, the hydrides are close to the temperature where they start showing some ductility.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: This probably is the reason why the $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ results in Table 5 show greater effect of hydrogen concentration on the corrosion rate than the $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ results.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: This probably is the reason why the $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ results in Table 5 show greater effect of hydrogen concentration on the corrosion rate than the $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ results.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: From the hydride ductility standpoint, a corrosion test temperature of $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ is expected to be better than $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ for correlating autoclave data with the in-PWR corrosion behavior.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: For metal-oxide interface temperatures greater than $\sim 7 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { K } }$ , the hydride phase is ductile and with increasing temperatures it can withstand the strains imposed by the growing oxide layer more effectively.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: Therefore the fracture of zirconium hydride precipitates does not significantly influence the corrosion rate at temperatures greater than $7 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { K } }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
